author: Darren Lewis
title: Red-hot Harry Kane well on his way to becoming a Tottenham legend believes Mauricio Pochettino
text:
Kane has three hat-tricks in nine games (Photo: 2017 Getty Images) Share Get football   Thank you for subscribing!   
Red-hot Harry Kane is already becoming a Spurs legend after reaching the 100 club according to Mauricio Pochettino. 
The 23-year-old striker blew Stoke apart with his third hat-trick in nine games to provide the perfect response to his side’s Europa League exit. 
With 22 goals now this season, Kane has become the first Spurs player since Jimmy Greaves to score 20 times three years in a row. 
Pochettino said: “Harry has the profile to be a legend. Maybe he’s starting to be a legend with the goals he’s scoring and the way he behaves. 
“He is so professional. He has the prefect profile to be a legend here. He has his character. Tottenham's Harry Kane scores their first goal in the thrashing of Spurs (Photo: REUTERS) Read More Harry Kane makes it to 100 career goals with first-half hat-trick against Stoke 
“I am pleased for him. He deserves it. He is very professional. A top man and I’m happy. It’s nothing new for me. I’ve said many times before that for me Harry is one of the best strikers in the world.” 
Kane also set up Dele Alli for Tottenham’s fourth, all before half time. It moves the north Londoners above Manchester City into second, ten points behind runaway leaders Chelsea. Kane is now favourite to land the golden boot once more (Photo: Getty) Kane also teed up Dele Alli (Photo: Michael Regan) 
Stoke boss Mark Hughes said: “Harry either takes chances, creates them or he’s involved in creation of chances. He is always involved at the sharp end. 
“There’s great movement around him and that causes consternation. He benefits from that. He’s in a good team and he’s a good player and when it all clicks they’re very difficult to stop.” 
The defeat was the second in six games for the Potters. Hughes believes his players showed their title-challenging hosts too much respect. LONDON, ENGLAND - FEBRUARY 26: Mark Hughes, Manager of Stoke City looks on during the Premier League match between Tottenham Hotspur and Stoke City at White Hart Lane on February 26, 2017 in London, England. (Photo by Michael Regan/Getty Images) (Photo: 2017 Getty Images) Read More Mark Hughes urges Tottenham midfielder Dele Alli not to change his game 
He said: “We were never out the traps. We talked about a bright start but it didn’t materialise. We were a little bit too passive. 
“We allowed good players time to get shots off. Every one of the goals was poor from our point view. We were slightly better second half, but that was more to do with Spurs taking their foot off the gas. 
“At times a little bit awe-struck maybe. We gave them too much respect. As a consequence we were picked off.” poll loading Will Harry Kane be Tottenham's all-time scorer? 0+ VOTES SO FAR
